channel.title: Hooks
channel.description: I noticed some people talking about these so called "hooks". Can someone explain me what they are and what they are used for?

item.title: Hooks
item.dc:creator: @pplsuqbawlz pplsuqbawlz
item.description:
@pplsuqbawlz wrote:

Lol. Reflection is ungodly slower in comparison to interface access. Interface is just maybe half as fast after about 1 million calls to it… Interface access however is a proper java practice: see DataInput and DataInputStream etc and the same for “DataOutput” yadda-yadda. Reflection is slower for various reason’s, but interface is only slightly slower than direct access because it’s managing multiple objects… It is however much faster than Reflection.

Sorta like an interface is a Road Map. If you don’t know where you’re going, it shows you. But just knowing the local roadways is of course, faster. Reflection is like launching a drone above you with a camera on the bottom of it, taking it, looking at the camera to see the roads, then deciding from all of that where to go… Reflection is more time taking etc… Maybe the only plus in it is that you see where traffic is? LOL. (Method and field modifiers? haha types?)[br][size=1]Posted on: February 26, 2007, 12:10:30 PM[/size][hr]Also interfaces give us tangible access we can touch in our own files; The whole thing behind Java is it’s “object oriented programming” etiquette stuffs.

Also it seems I might have been unclear: Using interfaces is ALMOST as fast as directly accessing an object. Reflection is VASTLY slower taking more time and much more processing/memory.

So to sum it up: Direct > Interface > Abstract > Reflection.

In other words, everything is greater than Reflection.

Read full topic

Read full topic

item.title: Hooks
item.dc:creator: @byte byte
item.description:
@byte wrote:

A hook, simply said, is an event handler. Hooks are implemented through callback functions. For a bot’s purpose we are interested in two hook types, on field mutation and on function entry/exit. These are called application hooks, system hooks also exist where by events such as mouse move, key type, new message (win32) are handled/filtered before processing.

In a bot’s scope, a field mutation and function entry hook could be implemented as such:

//bot code
class Hooks {
 private int i;
 public static void notifyIMutation(int i) {
  //filter if necessary
  this.i = i;
 }
 public static void notifyYEntry() {
  //handle
 }
}

//client code
class client {
 private int i;
 public void y(int a) {
  Hooks.notifyYEntry();
  i = a * 2;
  Hooks.notifyIMutation(i);
}

The obvious advantage is speed. In this case all we are doing is calling our notify function instead of going through the reflection rountines simply to retrieve the data of a newly mutated field.

Read full topic

item.title: Hooks
item.dc:creator: @frank frank_
item.description:
@frank wrote:

i dont know about everyone else, but when i say hook, this is what im talking about

a hook is something that we put (or inject) into the client, usually using a bytecode library. they are used to access specific fields

for example in the ‘stringwrapper’ class, there is a byte array field used to store the String data, we would then insert a method (the accessor, the hook, whatever you wish to call it) to pull that data

beforeclass StringWrapper { byte[] data; }

after[code]class StringWrapper {
byte[] data;

public byte[] getData() {
    return data;
}

}[/code]

Read full topic
